title: RAF Flying Training Command
text:
Flying Training Command was an <a href="Command%20%28military%20formation%29">organization</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a>; it controlled <a href="flight%20training">flight training</a> units. The command's headquarters were at <a href="Shinfield%20Park">Shinfield Park</a>, <a href="Reading%2C%20Berkshire">Reading</a> in <a href="Berkshire">Berkshire</a>.
History.
Flying Training Command was formed from the elements of <a href="RAF%20Training%20Command">Training Command</a> which were responsible for flying training on 27 May 1940; <a href="RAF%20Reserve%20Command">Reserve Command</a>, formed 1 February 1939, was absorbed into Flying Training Command on the same date. The remainder of Training Command became <a href="RAF%20Technical%20Training%20Command">Technical Training Command</a> on the same date. <a href="No.%2021%20Group%20RAF">No. 21 Group RAF</a> was transferred to Flying Training Command on 27 May 1940, responsible for the RAF College and the Service Flight Training Schools from the Midlands northwards. Nos 50, 51, and 54 Groups were flying training formations transferred from Reserve Command to Flying Training Command when it was formed. 
In March 1943 the command included Nos 21, 23, 25, and <a href="No.%2029%20Group%20RAF">29</a>, 50, 51, and 54 Groups.
<a href="No.%2023%20Group%20RAF">No. 23 Group RAF</a> was reformed as No 23 (Training) Group in Inland Area on 12 Apr 1926, at <a href="RAF%20Spitalgate">RAF Spitalgate</a>, by re-numbering <a href="No.%203%20Group%20RAF">No. 3 Group RAF</a>. Its stations were Digby, Eastchurch, Flowerdown, Manston, and <a href="RAF%20Sealand">RAF Sealand</a>, while it commanded 1 (Netheravon), 2, and 5 FTSs; the Armament and Gunnery School at Eastchurch; the SoTT (Airmen) at <a href="RAF%20Manston">RAF Manston</a>; the <a href="Central%20Flying%20School">Central Flying School</a> at <a href="RAF%20Upavon">RAF Upavon</a>, and finally the <a href="No.%201%20Radio%20School%20RAF">Electrical and Wireless School</a> at <a href="RAF%20Flowerdown">RAF Flowerdown</a>. 23 Group was transferred to <a href="RAF%20Training%20Command">RAF Training Command</a> on 1 May 1936. The RAF List for 1938 records that it comprised the Central Flying School; 1-3 and 5-11 Flying Training Schools; the Packing Depot at Sealand; the School of Air Navigation and <a href="No.%2048%20Squadron%20RAF">No. 48 Squadron RAF</a> at Manston; the Station Flight and No. 24 MU at <a href="Tern%20Hill">Tern Hill</a>; and No. 27 MU at <a href="RAF%20Shawbury">RAF Shawbury</a>. In September 1939 it controlled <a href="No.%201%20Service%20Flying%20Training%20School%20RAF">Nos 1</a>, <a href="No.%202%20Service%20Flying%20Training%20School%20RAF">2</a>, <a href="No.%203%20Service%20Flying%20Training%20School%20RAF">3</a>, <a href="No.%205%20Service%20Flying%20Training%20School%20RAF">5</a>, 6, 7, 9, 10, 11, and <a href="No.%2012%20Service%20Flying%20Training%20School%20RAF">12 Service Flying Training School</a>s, the <a href="Aeroplane%20and%20Armament%20Experimental%20Establishment">Aeroplane and Armament Experimental Establishment</a> at <a href="RAF%20Martlesham%20Heath">RAF Martlesham Heath</a>, and the group communications flight co-located with Group Headquarters at <a href="RAF%20Spitalgate">RAF Spitalgate</a> in <a href="Lincolnshire">Lincolnshire</a>. It was then transferred again to Flying Training Command on 27 May 1940. It was reabsorbed into Training Command in 1968 and disbanded on 2 May 1975.
In mid-1965 the Command was made up of No. 23 Group, No. 25 Group, the <a href="RAF%20College%20Cranwell">RAF College Cranwell</a>, the <a href="RAF%20Staff%20College">RAF Staff College</a>, Bracknell, the <a href="Central%20Flying%20School">Central Flying School</a>, and the College of Air Warfare.
Flying Training Command was eventually re-absorbed into the newly re-established Training Command on 1 June 1968.
Shinfield Park.
After Flying Training Command left, the <a href="Meteorological%20Office">Meteorological Office</a> College relocated from <a href="Stanmore">Stanmore</a>, Middlesex in October 1971. In 2004 both the College and the Met. Office HQ in <a href="Bracknell">Bracknell</a> relocated to <a href="Exeter">Exeter</a>, <a href="Devon">Devon</a>. The site has since been developed into residential accommodation, although "The Lodge", the centrepiece of Shinfield Park and a Georgian listed building, remains and is waiting redevelopment.
